definition:
The *chromatic number* of a graph is the minimum number of colours
required to colour it.

Consider the following graph:

$$\xymatrix{
{\color{red}A} \ar@{-}[r] & {\color{blue}B} \ar@{-}[r] \ar@{-}[d] & {\color{red}C} \ar@{-}[r] \ar@{-}[dl] & {\color{green}F} \ar@{-}[dl] \\
& {\color{green}D} \ar@{-}[r] & {\color{blue}E} & }$$

This graph has been coloured using $3$ colours. Furthermore, it’s clear
that it cannot be coloured with fewer than $3$ colours, as well: it
contains a subgraph ($BCD$) that is isomorphic to the complete graph of
$3$ vertices. As a result, the chromatic number of this graph is indeed
$3$.

This example was easy to solve by inspection. In general, however,
finding the chromatic number of a large graph (and, similarly, an
optimal colouring) is a very difficult (NP-hard) problem.
